Indications and doses

Superficial eye infections,

To the eye using eye ointment

  • For adults
    Apply 1 drop every 2 hours then reduce frequency as infection is controlled and continue for 48 hours after healing, frequency dependent on the severity of the infection. For less severe infection 3–4 times daily is generally sufficient.
  • For adults
    Apply daily, to be applied at night (if eye drops used during the day), alternatively apply 3–4 times a day, if ointment used alone.
  • For children
    Apply 1 drop every 2 hours then reduce frequency as infection is controlled and continue for 48 hours after healing, frequency dependent on the severity of the infection. For less severe infection 3–4 times daily is generally sufficient.
  • For children
    Apply daily, to be applied at night (if eye drops used during the day), alternatively apply 3–4 times a day, if ointment used alone.

Bacterial infection in otitis externa,

To the ear

  • For adults
    Apply 2–3 drops 2–3 times a day.
  • For children
    Apply 2–3 drops 2–3 times a day.

Life threatening infections particularly those caused by Haemophilus infuenzae , Typhoid fever,

By mouth or by intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    12.5 mg/kg every 6 hours, in exceptional cases dose can be doubled for severe infections such as septicaemia and meningitis, providing high doses reduced as soon as clinically indicated.

Drug action

Chloramphenicol is a potent broad-spectrum antibiotic.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intravenous use or oral use

Manufacturer advises avoid; neonatal ‘grey-baby syndrome’ if used in third trimester.

When used by eye

Avoid unless essential—no information on topical use but risk of ‘neonatal grey-baby syndrome’ with oral use in third trimester.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With intravenous use or oral use

Reduce dose.

With intravenous use or oral use

Avoid if possible—increased risk of bone-marrow depression.

Advice regarding renal impairment

With intravenous use or oral use

Avoid in severe renal impairment unless no alternative; dose-related depression of haematopoiesis.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: high incidence of sensitivity reactions to vehicle,

notKnown: transient stinging, blood disorders, depression, diarrhoea, dry mouth, erythema multiforme, glossitis, grey syndrome in neonates, headache, nausea, nocturnal haemoglobinuria, optic neuritis, peripheral neuritis, reversible and irreversible aplastic anaemia (with reports of resulting leukaemia), stomatitis, urticaria, vomiting, blood disorders, depression, diarrhoea, dry mouth, erythema multiforme, glossitis, headache, nausea, nocturnal haemoglobinuria, optic neuritis, peripheral neuritis, reversible and irreversible aplastic anaemia (with reports of resulting leukaemia), stomatitis, urticaria, vomiting,

With intravenous use in neonates

Grey syndrome

Grey syndrome (abdominal distension, pallid cyanosis, circulatory collapse) may follow excessive doses in neonates with immature hepatic metabolism.

With intravenous use or oral use

Associated with serious haematological side-effects when given systemically and should therefore be reserved for the treatment of life-threatening infections.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

Displacement value may be significant for injection, consult local guidelines. For intermittent intravenous infusion, dilute reconstituted solution further in glucose 5% or sodium chloride 0.9%.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Kemicetine ), give intermittently or via drip tubing in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%.

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by ear: avoid prolonged use
  • With intravenous use: avoid repeated courses and prolonged treatment
  • With oral use: avoid repeated courses and prolonged treatment

Monitoring requirements

Therapeutic drug monitoring

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Plasma concentration monitoring preferred in the elderly.

With intravenous use or oral use in children

Plasma concentration monitoring preferred in those under 4 years of age.

With intravenous use or oral use in neonates

Plasma concentration monitoring required in neonates. Grey baby syndrome may follow excessive doses in neonates with immature hepatic metabolism.

With intravenous use or oral use

Recommended peak plasma concentration (approx. 2 hours after administration by mouth, intravenous injection or infusion) 10–25 mg/litre; pre-dose (‘trough’) concentration should not exceed 15 mg/litre.

Patient parameters

With intravenous use or oral use

Blood counts required before and periodically during treatment.

Unlicensed use

When used by ear in children

Licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturers).

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

When used by eye

Although multi-dose chloramphenicol eye drops commonly contain preservatives, preservative-free unit dose vials may be available.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

When used by ear

Chloramphenicol ear drops are less suitable for prescribing.

Exceptions to legal category

When used by eye

Chloramphenicol 0.5% eye drops (in max. pack size 10 mL) and 1% eye ointment (in max. pack size 4 g) can be sold to the public for treatment of acute bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and children over 2 years; max. duration of treatment 5 days.
